questions.question: You’re offered a big promotion but it means public speaking every week. You:
choices: Turn it down instantly—too scary
Feel terrified but accept anyway
Say yes, then panic and try to back out
Feel nervous but excited

questions.question: The best way you’ve ever beaten a fear in the past was:
choices: Avoiding it forever
Gradual exposure—small steps until it wasn’t scary
One huge leap that traumatized you
Waiting until it magically went away

questions.question: You have to give a toast at a wedding in front of 150 people. Your approach:
choices: Fake being sick to get out of it
Practice a little every day until it feels normal
Wing it and hope adrenaline carries you
Drink heavily beforehand

questions.question: When fear hits, your body’s signals (racing heart, sweaty palms) usually make you:
choices: Freeze or shut down completely
Notice them, breathe, and keep moving forward
Get angry at yourself for being weak
Run away immediately

questions.question: You’re lost in a sketchy area at night. Your instinct is to:
choices: Panic and call someone crying
Stay calm, find a safe route, and walk confidently
Hide and wait for morning
Scream for help nonstop

questions.question: You see “face your fears” advice online. Your honest reaction:
choices: That’s stupid and dangerous
It’s scary but it actually works
Only works for other people
I’ll try it someday… maybe

questions.question: After a scary event (accident, bad news, etc.), how long until you feel normal again?
choices: Weeks or months—I never really get over it
A few days if I actively process it
Years, it haunts me
I bounce back the same day

questions.question: Someone dares you to do something that genuinely terrifies you (safe but scary). You:
choices: Refuse—no way
Do it while shaking but prove you can
Back out at the last second
Make excuses and leave

questions.question: Your fear of failure or rejection usually stops you from:
choices: Almost everything important
Some things, but I push through the big ones
Only minor stuff
Nothing—I go for it anyway

questions.question: When you think about your biggest remaining fear, your plan is:
choices: Keep avoiding it forever
Chip away at it with small, deliberate steps
One day I’ll just rip the band-aid off
Hope life never forces me to face it

score.high: Fear-Proof Warrior  Fear knocks, you open the door and invite it in for tea—then kick it out stronger.
score.medium: Courage in Training  You feel the fear but do it anyway most of the time. Keep going—you’re almost unbreakable.
score.low: Fear’s Favorite Guest  It still runs the show more than you’d like. The good news? Resilience is a skill anyone can build.
